Title:
Ancient polyploidy in Sidalcea and Eremalche (Malvaceae):
inference from NRPA2 and NRPB2 gene trees
Keywords:
angiosperms, gene duplications, ancient polyploidy,
paralog sorting, diploidization, low-copy nuclear DNA
Abstract:
Premise of the study: Sidalcea and Eremalche are putative
sister-genera from western North America. A polyploidization event
preceding the divergence of these taxa is suggested by their shared
basic chromosome number x = 10, which is an exact doubling of the
inferred ancestral number x = 5. Had polyploidy occurred, it would have
caused the immediate duplication of all nuclear genes, for which some
evidence might persist if not confounded by subsequent lineage sorting,
recombination, or gene conversion. Methods: We sequenced 361 cloned
isolates from two nuclear genes (NRPA2 and NRPB2) in Sidalcea and other
members of Malvaceae tribe Malveae. After screening for possible
pseudogenes or recombinants, we estimated separate Bayesian gene trees
from the genomic NRPA2 and NRPB2 sequence alignments. Key results: The
phylogenetic distribution of NRPA2 and NRPB2 gene duplications is
consistent with ancient polyploidy in the SidalceaEremalche lineage.
Subsequent episodes of paralog sorting (possibly associated with
diploidization) are needed to explain the overall pattern in the NRPA2
and NRPB2 gene trees. We estimate a minimum age of 6.2 mya for the
SidalceaEremalche whole-genome duplication (95% highest probability
density 1.2 to 11.7 mya). Conclusions: Polyploidy has occurred
repeatedly in angiosperm evolution, with events of different ages
representing a near continuum from “neopolyploid” to “paleopolyploid.”
For the SidalceaEremalche event, the term “mesopolyploid” would seem to
be appropriate as the diploidization process has not yet obscured the
obvious signs of genome duplication, even though the diploid progenitors
of this polyploid lineage are evidently already extinct.
